title: Marc Elias
deleted: In 2010, Elias sought [[advisory opinions]] from the [[Federal Election Commission]], declaring that certain online<ref>{{cite web|title=Letter from Marc Elias to the Federal Elections Commission on behalf of Google (August 5, 2010)|url=https://www.fec.gov/files/legal/aos/76064.pdf|accessdate=October 23, 2017}}</ref><ref name=FBletter>{{cite web|title=Letter from Marc Elias to the Federal Election Commission on behalf of Facebook (April 26, 2011)|url=https://www.fec.gov/files/legal/aos/77149.pdf|accessdate=October 23, 2017}}</ref> advertisements were, like advertisements sent via text, covered by the "small items" and "impracticable" exemptions of the law that otherwise requires advertisements by political committees to include a disclaimer revealing who paid for them.<ref name=FBletter/> The commission granted the request involving character-limited search advertisements, and deadlocked on the request involving small display advertisements.

title: Marc Elias
added: In 2004 served as general counsel to John Kerry's presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite web| title=MARC ELIAS – general counsel for Hillary Clinton| url=https://www.chambers-associate.com/the-big-interview/marc-elias-general-counsel-for-hillary-clinton | accessdate=September 6, 2021}}</ref>

title: Marc Elias
added: * LULAC TEXAS; VOTO LATINO; TEXAS ALLIANCE FOR RETIRED AMERICANS; TEXAS AFT vs JOSE ESPARZA, in his official capacity as the Texas Deputy Secretary of State; [[Ken Paxton]], in his official capacity as the [[Texas Attorney General]]; JACQUELYN CALLANEN, in her official capacity as the Bexar County Elections Administrator; DANA DeBEAUVOIR, in her official capacity as the Travis County Clerk; ISABEL LONGORIA, in her official capacity as the Harris County Elections Administrator; YVONNE RAMÓN, in her official capacity as the Hidalgo County Elections Administrator; MICHAEL SCARPELLO, in his official capacity as the Dallas County Elections Administrator; LISA WISE, in her official capacity as the El Paso County Elections Administrator<ref>{{cite web| title=LULAC Texas v. Esparza | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2021/09/LULAC-Texas-v.-Esparza-FILED-COMPLAINT.pdf | accessdate=September 7, 2021}}</ref>

title: Marc Elias
added: * Virginia House of Delegates v. Bethune-Hill<ref>{{cite web| title=Virginia House of Delegates v. Bethune-Hill | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bethune-Hill-Amended-Complaint-1.pdf | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref> Lawsuit filed on behalf of 12 individual Virginia voters challenging the Virginia House of Delegates’ 2011 redistricting map on the basis that 12 House of Delegates districts were drawn as racial gerrymanders in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. The district court held that 11 of the House districts were unconstitutional racial gerrymanders.

title: Marc Elias
added: * Jacobson v. Lee<ref>{{cite web| title=Jacobson v. Lee | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2018-05-24-Florida-Ballot-Order-Complaint-1.pdf | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref> Lawsuit filed by individual voters, Priorities USA, Democratic National Committee (DNC), Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC), Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC), Democratic Governors Association (DGA) and Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee (DLCC) challenging Florida’s ballot order statute, which requires that candidates of the political party of the Governor be listed first on the ballot in all elections. The complaint alleges that this statute treats similarly situated candidates differently without sufficient justification and violates the First and 14th Amendments. The district court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the ballot order statute violates the First and 14th Amendments by taking “a side in partisan elections.” Republican intervenor-defendants appealed the decision to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which vacated the district court’s judgment and remanded the case with instructions to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction.

title: Marc Elias
added: * Dwight v. Raffensperger<ref>{{cite web| title=Dwight v. Raffensperger Amended Complaint | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/GA-Redistricting-Amended-Complaint-1.pdf | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref> Lawsuit filed on behalf of individual voters challenging Georgia’s 2011 congressional map for violating Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. The complaint alleges that the map dilutes the votes of African American communities from the 12th Congressional District in central-southeast Georgia — where African Americans had previously elected their preferred candidates — and submerges them in surrounding majority-white districts where they can no longer elect their candidates of choice. The parties entered a stipulation of dismissal.<ref>{{cite web| title=Georgia Congressional Redistricting (2011 Map) | url=https://www.democracydocket.com/cases/georgia-congressional-redistricting/ | accessdate=September 8, 2021}}</ref>
